Featured

The Silver Linings Playbook for New York’s Losing Season

Let’s look at what gets Knicks fans out of bed during this dismal season

To be born a New York Knicks fan is to be born a pessimist, and rightfully so as, over the past decade, the team has not provided very much to be optimistic about.

Set to endure yet another losing season, fans are left at a point where they have lost track of the amount of losing seasons in recent history. However, this might be a rare losing season that holds a few silver linings for a team in need of a major shakeup.

Solid draft positioning

2017 is proving to be a rare year where the Knicks have somehow not been bamboozled into losing their first round draft pick. That could prove invaluable as, from what we have seen thus far in the NCAA Tournament, there are plenty of players that the Knicks could select to get them from the road to perdition and instead line them up with a heap of young talent.

Per Tankathon, the Knicks currently possess the fourth best odds to win the NBA lottery, which would mean that players such as De’Aaron Fox from the University of Kentucky, Jayson Tatum of Duke University, or Jonathan Isaac of Florida State University could all be on the board at that spot.

At this point, the only player guaranteed a starting spot next season is Kristaps Porzingis, meaning that the Knicks should be looking to draft from a talent perspective, taking the best player available on the board, rather than trying to fill a position. The Knicks could very well put themselves in a position to have two dynamic young players to build around come October when the season tips off, a prospect that should prove tantalizing to fans.

Say goodbye to Derrick Rose and Carmelo Anthony, this is Porzingis’ team

After dubbing the Knicks as a super team during the offseason, both the Knicks and Rose have been anything close to that from a talent perspective. From apathetic defensive play to inefficiencies offensively, the only positive I can eek out of the Rose trade this past summer is that his contract was only a year long. Rose will be off the books, and barring any surprises, he, alongside his 0.5 defensive win shares, will not be re-signed by President of Basketball Operations Phil Jackson.

Alongside Rose, there is the potential that Anthony and his behemoth of a contract will be dealt as well. Speaking on January 21, 2017, Anthony mentioned the possibility of calling another city home (via Newsday).

“I have the power, but still I would talk to them. We would be in communication if they feel like they want to go in a different direction, they want to start rebuilding for the future. If they tell me they want to scrap this whole thing, yeah, I have to consider it.” (source)
Your Guide to the Knicks Tank
We go through the tanking teams’ remaining schedule and try to figure out where New York will land in the lottery oddstheknickswall.com

Showing a decline from his career averages, Anthony has averaged 22.7 points, 5.9 rebounds, and 2.9 assists on 43.5 percent shooting from the field and 36.1 percent shooting from three-point range (per BBall_Ref). Over the course of the season, Anthony has posted the lowest win shares of his career, contributing 4.6 total. Carmelo would reportedly only return, “as long as it’s mutual.”

Anthony’s departure would leave Porzingis as the star of the team, along with a high draft pick rookie and other role player pieces, officially beginning the process of a rebuild. This would allow for Kristaps to run the offense, and truly come into his own. Seeing his scoring numbers rise from 14.3 points per game to 18.0 points per game with his field-goal percentage also rise 2.2 percent, KP is putting himself in a prime spot to truly take the next step and become the team’s first option next season. It should be noted that all of these statistical increases by Porzingis were made with his usage percentage having decreased from 24.6 percent in his rookie year to 24.3 percent this season.

Development of Willy Hernangómez and Mindaugas Kuzminskas

The Knicks as a team present a lot of negatives, but if there has been one thing to praise in recent memory, it is the team’s European scouting department. The department has produced the team’s future superstar in Porzingis, while also finding potential future starters in Hernangómez and Kuzminskas.

Hernangómez has truly come into his own, pushing himself very much so in the conversation to be the starting center come next season (Editor’s note: what’s Joakim Noah up to the first ten games next year?). Having started the past 13 games, Willy’s sample size prior to that was riddled with inconsistencies due to his fluctuation in minutes.

If we take a look at Hernangómez’s Per 36, it’s very easy to see why he’s cemented himself as a competitor for the starting center spot as early as next season. Hernangómez has projected averages of 15.6 points per game, 13.9 rebounds per game, 2.4 assists per game, 1.2 blocks per game.

None of those numbers are statistical anomalies either for Willy as he’s proved to be a contributor based off of his production in the 13 starts. Hernangómez has been a bright spot this season, and likely for seasons to come for the Knicks, posting over 10 points on six occasions and over 10 rebounds on five occasions in his past ten games (seven starts).

Young Titans: Can Kristaps and Willy Flourish Together?
We take a look at the obvious chemistry between the young guns and ask if the big men pair are capable of shaping the…theknickswall.com

Playing largely off of the bench, but still managing five starts, Kuzminskas has been understated but has been a viable contributor at times. In an average of 14.4 minutes of game time a night, Kuz has posted 5.9 points, 1.9 rebounds, and 1.0 assist. That, though, does not tell the tale of the tape for the 27-year-old Lithuanian (via BBall_Ref).

In 11 games where Kuz has averaged double-digit scoring numbers, he has averaged 26.5 minutes of action. With that playing time, Mindy has averaged 14.7 points per game on 55.1 percent shooting from the field. Besides his impressive shooting, Kuzminskas has averaged 3.8 rebounds per game and 1.7 assists per game in those games where he has scored in double-digits.

Kuz has showed enormous potential to be, at the very least, a scoring threat off of the bench in his first season in the NBA. The ceiling is there to be a starter — Mindy would have to become more well rounded, but when given the minutes he has been a viable contributor in his rookie season.

There’s no denying that there is not a lot to be happy about as a Knicks fan this season, but there is evidence that the young talent is working and the Knicks might be able to escape the contracts that have plagued them for some time now, and transition into a new, dynamic team in the near future.

— Ankit Mehra, site writer
